qas.question: Bushi formed new associations in what century?
How did military families gain prestige?
Who were the three prominent families during the rise of the warrior classes?

answers.text: Fujiwara family, Taira clan, and Minamoto clan

qas.question: Who had limited intrests in the tenth century?
What groups became part of the centraladministration?

plausible_answers.text: military titles and access to manpower

qas.question: What did provincial aristocracy grant to the imperial court?

context: <b3_0>Bushi<b3_0/> interests were diverse, cutting across old power structures to form new associations in the <a0_0>tenth<a0_0/> century. Mutual interests, family connections, and kinship were consolidated in <b4_0>military groups<b4_0/> that became part of family administration. In time, <b5_0>large regional military families<b5_0/> formed around members of the court aristocracy who had become prominent provincial figures. These military families gained prestige from <a1_0>connections to the imperial court<a1_0/> and court-granted <b6_0>military titles and access to manpower<b6_0/>. The <a2_0>Fujiwara family, Taira clan, and Minamoto clan<a2_0/> were among the most prominent families supported by the new military class.
